trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the orc can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature it can see.

trait.name: Indomitable (2/Day)
entries: The orc rerolls a failed save. It must use the new roll.

trait.name: Punish the Marked (1/Turn)
entries: As a bonus action, the orc can make a melee weapon attack against a creature marked by it if the creature dealt damage to anyone other than the orc during the last turn. The orc's melee weapon attack has advantage on the attack roll, and if it hits, the attack's weapon deals an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) damage to the target.

trait.name: Threatening
entries: Creatures provoke an {@action opportunity attack} from the orc when they move 5 feet or more while within the orc's reach, and if the orc hits a creature with an opportunity attack, the target's speed is reduced to 0 until the end of the current turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The orc makes three attacks with its greatsword or javelin.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage, and the target is marked until the end of the orc's next turn. This effect ends early if the orc is {@condition incapacitated} or it dies, or if someone else marks the target. While it is within 5 feet of the orc, a creature marked by the orc has disadvantage on any attack roll that doesn't target the orc.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) piercing damage, and the target is marked until the end of the orc's next turn. This effect ends early if the orc is {@condition incapacitated} or it dies, or if someone else marks the target. While it is within 5 feet of the orc, a creature marked by the orc has disadvantage on any attack roll that doesn't target the orc.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The orc adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the orc must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The kherberum can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the kherberum has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the kherberum fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The kherberum doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: True cold
entries: The kherberum attacks ignore cold resistance.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kherberum can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d10 + 4}) necrotic damage plus 4 ({@damage 3d8}) cold damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken. This reduction lasts until the creature finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d8 + 8}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the kherberum choice that is within 120 feet of the dragon and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Necrotic Cold Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The kherberum exhales an icy necrotic blast in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 8d8}) cold damage and 22 ({@damage 8d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The kherberum makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The kherberum makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The kherberum beats its wings. Each creature within 15 feet of the kherberum must succeed on a {@dc 22} Dexterity saving throw or take 15 ({@damage 2d6 + 8}) necrotic damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The kherberum can then fly up to half its flying speed.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Harshnag fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Rage (3/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, the Harshnag can enter a rage at the start of its turn. The rage lasts for 1 minute or until the Harshnag is {@condition incapacitated}. While raging, the Harshnag gains the following benefits:
• The Harshnag has advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
• When it makes a melee weapon attack, the Harshnag gains a +4 bonus to the damage roll.
• The Harshnag has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
• The Harshnag can make a single melee weapon attack as a bonus action.
• The Harshnag can't be {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the Harshnag can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the harshnag can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes three greataxe attacks.

action.name: +2 Gurt's Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 3d12 + 9 + 4}) slashing damage, or 44 ({@damage 5d12 + 9 + 4}) slashing damage if the target is human.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 12} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 4d10 + 7 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature smaller than the giant, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Fragmented Rock
entries: The Harshnag shatters a huge boulder and hurls it in an area. Each creature in a 15-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 17 ({@damage 3d6+7}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Fling
entries: The Harshnag tries to throw a Small or Medium creature within 10 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw or be hurled up to 60 feet horizontally in a direction of the giant's choice and land {@condition prone}, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown.

action.name: Weighted Net
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, ranged 20/60 ft., one Small, Medium, or Large creature. {@h}The target is {@condition restrained} until it escapes the net. Any creature can use its action to make a {@dc 17} Strength check to free itself or another creature in the net, ending the effect on a success. Dealing 15 slashing damage to the net (AC 12) destroys the net and frees the target.

action.name: (GMA) - Squash|Esmagar - (GMA)
entries: O Harshnag se arremessa corporalmente em inimigos menores até 10-foot-radius, e os esmaga com seu peso, para isso o Harshnag faz uso de todo seu deslocamento. Uma criatura grande ou até 4 médias ou menores a até 5 feets uma da outra deve fazer um teste {@dc 15} de resistência de destreza, se falhar o alvo recebe 28 ({@damage 6d6+6}) de dano de bludgeoning. Além disso, o Harshnag fica {@condition prone} no espaço do alvo, e o alvo está {@condition restrained} e {@condition grapple}, no início do turno o alvo deve realizar um teste {@dc 15} de resistência de força encerrando o efeito em sucesso. Essas condições terminam cedo se o Harshnag se levantar.

action.name: (GMA) - Trample|Atropelar - (GMA)
entries: O Harshnag pode se mover normalmente por espaços ocupados por criaturas menores. Para fazer isso, o Harshnag deve fazer um teste de força (atletismo) resistida contra os alvos menores que estiverem no percurso. Se ele falhar, o movimento do Harshnag para naquele espaço e ele perde o resto do seu deslocamento. Se o Harshnag estiver duas ou mais categorias de tamanho acima, ele é automaticamente bem-sucedido. O Harshnag causa 10 ({@damage 1d8+7}) de dano de concussão em cada criatura que falhar no teste resistido.

action.name: (GMA) - Crush|Pisotear - (GMA)
entries: O Harshnag força um de seus pés sobre a cabeça de um alvo. A criatura deve ser bem sucedida em um teste {@dc 15} de resistência de Força. Em uma falha na resistência, a criatura está {@condition prone} e {@condition restrained}. No início de seu próximo turno, a criatura pode fazer um teste de força {@dc 15} (atletismo) ou destreza (acrobacia) para escapar. Se obtiver sucesso, a criatura vai para um espaço adjacente não ocupado e pode agir normalmente. Se o Harshnag se afastar da criatura, ela não está mais {@condition restrained}.

action.name: (GMA) - Crush|Pisotear - (GMA)
entries: O Harshnag força um de seus pés sobre a cabeça de um alvo. A criatura deve ser bem sucedida em um teste {@dc 15} de resistência de Força. Em uma falha na resistência, a criatura está {@condition prone} e {@condition restrained}. No início de seu próximo turno, a criatura pode fazer um teste de força {@dc 15} (atletismo) ou destreza (acrobacia) para escapar. Se obtiver sucesso, a criatura vai para um espaço adjacente não ocupado e pode agir normalmente. Se o Harshnag se afastar da criatura, ela não está mais {@condition restrained}.

Gigantic reavers from the freezing lands beyond civilization, frost giants are fierce, hardy warriors that survive on the spoils of their raids and pillaging.They respect only brute strength and skill in battle, demonstrating both with their scars and the grisly trophies they take from their enemies.

entries.name: Hearts of Ice
entries: Frost giants are creatures of ice and snow. Their hair and beards are pale white or light blue, matted with frost and clattering with icicles. Their flesh is as blue as glacial ice.

Frost giants dwell in high peaks and glacial rifts where the sun hides its golden head by winter. Crops don't grow in their frozen homelands, and they keep little livestock beyond what they capture in their raids against civilized lands. They hunt the wild game of the tundra and mountains but don't cook it, since meat from a fresh kill tastes sufficiently hot to their palate.

entries.name: Reavers of the Storm
entries: The war horns of the frost giants howl as they march from their ice fortresses and glacial rifts amid the howling blizzard. When thatstorm clears, villages and steadings lay in ruins, ravens descending to feed on the corpses of any creatures foolish or unlucky enough to stand in the giants' path.

Inns and taverns suffer the brunt of the damage, their cellars gutted and their casks of ale and mead gone. Smithies are likewise toppled, their iron and steel claimed. Curiously undisturbed are the houses of moneylenders and wealthy citizens, for the reavers have little use for coins or baubles. Frost giants prize gems and jewelry large enough to be worn and noticed. However, even those treasures are most often saved for trading opportunities with other giants more adept at crafting metal weapons and armor.

entries.name: Rulers by Might
entries: Frost giants respect brute strength above all else, and a frost giant's place in the ordning depends on evidence of physical might, such as superior musculature, scars from battles of renown, or trophies fashioned from the bodies of slain enemies. Tasks such as hunting, childrearing, and crafting are given to giants based on their physical strength and hardiness.

When frost giants of different clans meet and their status is unclear, they wrestle for dominance. Such meetings might resemble festivals where giants cheer on their champions, making bold boasts and challenges. At other times, the informal ceremony can become a chaotic free-for-all where both clans rush into a melee that fells trees, shatters the ice on frozen lakes, and causes avalanches on the snowy mountainsides.

entries.name: Make War, Not Goods
entries: Though frost giants consider the menial crafting of goods beneath them, carving and leatherwork are valued skills. They make their clothing from the skins and bones of beasts, and carve bone or ivory into jewelry and the handles of weapons and tools. They reuse the weapons and armor of their smaller foes, stringing shields into scale armor and lashing sword blades to wooden hafts to make giant-sized spears. The greatest battle trophies come from conquered dragons, and the greatest frost giant jarls wear armor of dragon scales or wield picks and mauls made of a dragon's teeth or claws.

entries.name: Giants
entries: Ancient empires once cast long shadows over a world that quaked beneath the giants' feet. In those lost days, these towering figures were dragon slayers, dreamers, crafters, and kings, but their kind fell from glory long ago. However, even divided among secluded clans scattered throughout the world, the giants maintain the customs and traditions of old.

entries.name: Old as Legend
entries: In remote regions of the world, the last remaining plinths, monoliths, and statues of the great giant empires bow their heads in desolate obscurity.Where once those empires sprawled across all lands, now the giants dwell in isolated tribes and clans.

Giants are almost as old as dragons, which were still young when the giants' heavy feet first shook the foundations of the world. As they spread across new lands, giants and dragons fought bitter generational wars that nearly brought both sides low. No living giant remembers what started the conflict, but myths and tales of their race's glorious dawn are still sung in their steadings and holdfasts, vilifying the primeval wyrms.Giants and dragons continue to harbor grudges against one another, and it is seldom that they will meet or occupy the same area without a fight.

entries.name: The Ordning
entries: Each of the main giant races-the cloud, fire, frost, hill, stone, and storm giants-are related by common elements of history, religion, and culture. They view one another as kindred, keeping any inherent animosity over territory and ambition to a minimum.

Giants belong to a caste structure called the ordning. Based on social class and highly organized, the ordning assigns a social rank to each giant. By understanding its place in the ordning, a giant knows which other giants are inferior or superior to it, since no two giants are equal. Each of the giant races analyzes a different combination of skills or qualities to determine the ordning. Giants make excelling in these qualities the purpose of their lives.

At the highest level of the ordning, the races of the giants are also ranked according to status. Storm giants are the highest in the ordning, followed by cloud giants, fire giants, frost giants, stone giants, hill giants, and finally giant kin such as fomorians, ettins, and ogres.

Regardless of a giant's rank among its own race, the chief of a hill giant tribe is inferior to the most common of stone giants. The lowest ranked giant of any type is superior to the highest ranked giant of an inferior type. It isn't considered evil to disrespect or even betray a giant of another type, merely rude.

entries.name: Giant Gods
entries: When the giants' ancient empires fell, Annam, father of all giants, forsook his children and the world. He swore never to look upon either again until the giants had returned to their glory and reclaimed their birthright as rulers of the world. As a result, giants pray not to Annam but to his divine children, along with a host of hero-deities and godly villains that make up the giants' pantheon.

Chief among these gods are the children of Annam, whose sons represent each type of giant: Stronmaus for storm giants, Memnor for cloud giants, Skoraeus Stonebones for stone giants, Thrym for frost giants, Surtur for fire giants, and Grolantor for hill giants. Not all giants automatically revere their kind's primary deity, however. Many good cloud giants refuse to worship the deceitful Memnor, and a storm giant dwelling in the icy mountains of the north might pay more homage to Thrym than Stronmaus. Other giants feel a stronger connection to Annam's daughters, who include Hiatea, the huntress and home warden; Iallanis, goddess of love and peace; and Diancastra, an impetuous and arrogant trickster.

Some giants abandon their own gods and fall prey to demon cults, paying homage to Baphomet or Kostchtchie. To worship them or any other non-giant deity is a great sin against the ordning, and almost certain to make a giant an outcast.

trait.name: Stone Camouflage
entries: The giant has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in rocky terrain.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two greatclub attacks.

action.name: Greatclub
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature smaller than the giant, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Fling
entries: The giant tries to throw a Small or Medium creature within 10 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or be hurled up to 60 feet horizontally in a direction of the giant's choice and land {@condition prone}, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown.

action.name: Rolling Rock
entries: The giant sends a rock tumbling along the ground in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage and falling {@condition prone} on a failed save"

entries: O gigante se arremessa corporalmente em inimigos menores até 10-foot-radius, e os esmaga com seu peso, para isso o gigante faz uso de todo seu deslocamento. Uma criatura grande ou até 4 médias ou menores a até 5 feets uma da outra deve fazer um teste {@dc 14} de resistência de destreza, se falhar o alvo recebe 28 ({@damage 6d6+6}) de dano de bludgeoning. Além disso, o gigante fica {@condition prone} no espaço do alvo, e o alvo está {@condition restrained} e {@condition grapple}, no início do turno o alvo deve realizar um teste {@dc 14} de resistência de força encerrando o efeito em sucesso. Essas condições terminam cedo se o gigante se levantar.

action.name: (GMA) - Trample|Atropelar - (GMA)
entries: O gigante pode se mover normalmente por espaços ocupados por criaturas menores. Para fazer isso, o gigante deve fazer um teste de força (atletismo) resistida contra os alvos menores que estiverem no percurso. Se ele falhar, o movimento do gigante para naquele espaço e ele perde o resto do seu deslocamento. Se o gigante estiver duas ou mais categorias de tamanho acima, ele é automaticamente bem-sucedido. O gigante causa 10 ({@damage 1d8+6}) de dano de concussão em cada criatura que falhar no teste resistido.

action.name: (GMA) - Crush|Pisotear - (GMA)
entries: O gigante força um de seus pés sobre a cabeça de um alvo. A criatura deve ser bem sucedida em um teste {@dc 14} de resistência de Força. Em uma falha na resistência, a criatura está {@condition prone} e {@condition restrained}. No início de seu próximo turno, a criatura pode fazer um teste de força {@dc 14} (atletismo) ou destreza (acrobacia) para escapar. Se obtiver sucesso, a criatura vai para um espaço adjacente não ocupado e pode agir normalmente. Se o gigante se afastar da criatura, ela não está mais {@condition restrained}.

action.name: (GMA) - Jump|Salto - (GMA)
entries: O gigante salta sobre uma superfície, gerando um tremor e potencialmente desequilibrando as criaturas que estiverem sobre a superfície que o gigante aterrissar, para isso o gigante faz uso de todo seu deslocamento, podendo ainda assim aterrissar em algum ponto a 20 feets de onde estava. As criaturas que estiverem a 10 feets do gigante ou sobre ele devem ser bem sucedidas em um teste {@dc 14} de resistência de destreza, em uma falha a criatura está {@condition prone}. Adicionalmente, se houver alguma criatura no espaço do gigante enquanto ele realiza esta ação, o teste de resistência deve ser feito com desvantagem, em uma falha o alvo sofre 20 ({@damage 3d8+6}) de dano de concussão, em sucesso o alvo recebe apenas metade do dano.

reaction.name: Rock Catching
entries: If a rock or similar object is hurled at the giant, the giant can, with a successful {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw, catch the missile and take no bludgeoning damage from it.

variant.name: New Giant Options
entries: Some adult stone giants like to grab enemies and fling them through the air. They can also roll boulders across the ground, striking multiple enemies in a line. These abilities are represented by the following action options.

entries.name: Fling
entries: The giant tries to throw a Small or Medium creature within 10 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or be hurled up to 60 feet horizontally in a direction of the giant's choice and land {@condition prone}, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown.

entries.name: Rolling Rock
entries: The giant sends a rock tumbling along the ground in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage and falling {@condition prone} on a failed save

Stone giants are reclusive, quiet, and peaceful as long as they are left alone. Their granite-gray skin, gaunt features, and black, sunken eyes endow stone giants with a stern countenance. They are private creatures, hiding their lives and art away from the world.

entries.name: Inhabitants of a Stone World
entries: Secluded caves are the homes of the stone giants. Cavern networks are their towns, rocky tunnels their roads, and underground streams their waterways. Isolated mountain ranges are their continents, with the vast spans of land between seen as oceans that the stone giants only rarely cross.

In their dark, quiet caves, stone giants wordlessly chip away at elaborate carvings, measuring time in the echoing drip of water into cavern pools. In the deepest chambers of a stone giant settlement, far from the chittering of bats or the patrols paced out by the giants' cave bear companions, are holy places where silence and darkness are complete. Stone takes on its most sacred quality in these cavern cathedrals, their buttresses and columns carved with a beauty that shames the legendary stone craft of the dwarves.

entries.name: Carvers and Seers
entries: Among stone giants, artistry ranks as the greatest virtue. They create intricate murals, paint sprawling murals across cavern walls, and indulge in a wide variety of other artistic disciplines. They esteem stone carving as the greatest of skills.

Stone giants strive to draw shapes out of raw stone, which they believe reveal meaning inspired by their god, Skoraeus Stonebones. The giants appoint the tribe's best carvers as their leaders, shamans, and prophets. The holy hands of such giants become the hands of the god as they work.

entries.name: Graceful Athletes
entries: Despite their great size and musculature, stone giants are lithe and graceful. Skilled rock throwers are granted positions of high rank in the giants' ordning, testing and demonstrating their ability to hurl and catch enormous boulders. Such giants take the front ranks when a tribe has cause to defend its home or attack its enemies. However, even in combat, artistry is key. A stone giant hurling a rock performs not just a feat of brute strength but also one of stunning athleticism and poise.

entries.name: Dreamers under Sky
entries: Stone giants view the world outside their underground homes as a realm of dreams where nothing is entirely true or real. They behave in the surface world the way humanoids might behave in their own dreams, making little account for their actions and never fully trusting what they see or hear. A promise made above ground need not be kept. Insults can be made without apology. Killing prey or sentient beings is no cause for guilt in the dreaming world beneath the sky.

Stone giants lacking in athletic grace or artistic skill dwell at the fringes of their society, serving as the tribe's outlying guardians and far-wandering hunters. When trespassers stray too far into the mountain territory of a stone giant clan, those guardians greet them with hurled rocks and showers of splintered stone. Survivors of such encounters spread tales of stone giant violence, never realizing how little those brutes dwelling in the unreal dreaming world resemble their quiet and artistic kin.

entries.name: Giants
entries: Ancient empires once cast long shadows over a world that quaked beneath the giants' feet. In those lost days, these towering figures were dragon slayers, dreamers, crafters, and kings, but their kind fell from glory long ago. However, even divided among secluded clans scattered throughout the world, the giants maintain the customs and traditions of old.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The wolf has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The wolf has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the wolf's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The wolf has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Savage Howl {@recharge 5}
entries: As a bonus action, the wolf emits a terrifying howl that also rallies its allies. Each ally that is within 30 feet of it, can hear it, and not already affected by Savage Howl gain advantage on attack rolls and saving throw rolls until the start of the wolf's next turn. All other creatures within 30 feet must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the wolf Savage Howl for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Cold Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The wolf exhales a blast of freezing wind in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two greataxe attacks.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 3d12 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature smaller than the giant, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Fragmented Rock
entries: The giant shatters a huge boulder and hurls it in an area. Each creature in a 15-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 20 ({@damage 3d8+6}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Fling
entries: The giant tries to throw a Small or Medium creature within 10 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or be hurled up to 60 feet horizontally in a direction of the giant's choice and land {@condition prone}, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown.

action.name: Weighted Net
entries: The giant throws a net at 60 feet of it. The net is a 10-foot cube. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target is {@condition restrained} until it escapes the net. One creature can use its action to make a {@dc 17} Strength check to free itself or another creature in the net, ending the effect on a success. Dealing 30 slashing damage to the net (AC 13) destroys the net and frees the target.

action.name: (GMA) - Squash|Esmagar - (GMA)
entries: O gigante se arremessa corporalmente em inimigos menores até 10-foot-radius, e os esmaga com seu peso, para isso o gigante faz uso de todo seu deslocamento. Uma criatura grande ou até 4 médias ou menores a até 5 feets uma da outra deve fazer um teste {@dc 14} de resistência de destreza, se falhar o alvo recebe 28 ({@damage 6d6+6}) de dano de bludgeoning. Além disso, o gigante fica {@condition prone} no espaço do alvo, e o alvo está {@condition restrained} e {@condition grapple}, no início do turno o alvo deve realizar um teste {@dc 14} de resistência de força encerrando o efeito em sucesso. Essas condições terminam cedo se o gigante se levantar.

action.name: (GMA) - Trample|Atropelar - (GMA)
entries: O gigante pode se mover normalmente por espaços ocupados por criaturas menores. Para fazer isso, o gigante deve fazer um teste de força (atletismo) resistida contra os alvos menores que estiverem no percurso. Se ele falhar, o movimento do gigante para naquele espaço e ele perde o resto do seu deslocamento. Se o gigante estiver duas ou mais categorias de tamanho acima, ele é automaticamente bem-sucedido. O gigante causa 10 ({@damage 1d8+6}) de dano de concussão em cada criatura que falhar no teste resistido.

action.name: (GMA) - Crush|Pisotear - (GMA)
entries: O gigante força um de seus pés sobre a cabeça de um alvo. A criatura deve ser bem sucedida em um teste {@dc 14} de resistência de Força. Em uma falha na resistência, a criatura está {@condition prone} e {@condition restrained}. No início de seu próximo turno, a criatura pode fazer um teste de força {@dc 14} (atletismo) ou destreza (acrobacia) para escapar. Se obtiver sucesso, a criatura vai para um espaço adjacente não ocupado e pode agir normalmente. Se o gigante se afastar da criatura, ela não está mais {@condition restrained}.

action.name: (GMA) - Jump|Salto - (GMA)
entries: O gigante salta sobre uma superfície, gerando um tremor e potencialmente desequilibrando as criaturas que estiverem sobre a superfície que o gigante aterrissar, para isso o gigante faz uso de todo seu deslocamento, podendo ainda assim aterrissar em algum ponto a 20 feets de onde estava. As criaturas que estiverem a 10 feets do gigante ou sobre ele devem ser bem sucedidas em um teste {@dc 14} de resistência de destreza, em uma falha a criatura está {@condition prone}. Adicionalmente, se houver alguma criatura no espaço do gigante enquanto ele realiza esta ação, o teste de resistência deve ser feito com desvantagem, em uma falha o alvo sofre 20 ({@damage 3d8+6}) de dano de concussão, em sucesso o alvo recebe apenas metade do dano.

variant.name: New Giant Options
entries: Some adult frost giants are skilled hunters who construct and hurl nets weighted down with fragments of metal or bone. This ability is represented by the following action option.

entries.name: Weighted Net
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, ranged 20/60 ft., one Small, Medium, or Large creature. {@h}The target is {@condition restrained} until it escapes the net. Any creature can use its action to make a {@dc 17} Strength check to free itself or another creature in the net, ending the effect on a success. Dealing 15 slashing damage to the net (AC 12) destroys the net and frees the target.

Gigantic reavers from the freezing lands beyond civilization, frost giants are fierce, hardy warriors that survive on the spoils of their raids and pillaging. They respect only brute strength and skill in battle, demonstrating both with their scars and the grisly trophies they take from their enemies.

entries.name: Hearts of Ice
entries: Frost giants are creatures of ice and snow. Their hair and beards are pale white or light blue, matted with frost and clattering with icicles. Their flesh is as blue as glacial ice.

Frost giants dwell in high peaks and glacial rifts where the sun hides its golden head by winter. Crops don't grow in their frozen homelands, and they keep little livestock beyond what they capture in their raids against civilized lands. They hunt the wild game of the tundra and mountains but don't cook it, since meat from a fresh kill tastes sufficiently hot to their palate.

entries.name: Reavers of the Storm
entries: The war horns of the frost giants howl as they march from their ice fortresses and glacial rifts amid the howling blizzard. When that storm clears, villages and steadings lay in ruins, ravens descending to feed on the corpses of any creatures foolish or unlucky enough to stand in the giants' path.

Inns and taverns suffer the brunt of the damage, their cellars gutted and their casks of ale and mead gone. Smithies are likewise toppled, their iron and steel claimed. Curiously undisturbed are the houses of moneylenders and wealthy citizens, for the reavers have little use for coins or baubles. Frost giants prize gems and jewelry large enough to be worn and noticed. However, even those treasures are most often saved for trading opportunities with other giants more adept at crafting metal weapons and armor.

entries.name: Rulers by Might
entries: Frost giants respect brute strength above all else, and a frost giant's place in the ordning depends on evidence of physical might, such as superior musculature, scars from battles of renown, or trophies fashioned from the bodies of slain enemies. Tasks such as hunting, childrearing, and crafting are given to giants based on their physical strength and hardiness.

When frost giants of different clans meet and their status is unclear, they wrestle for dominance. Such meetings might resemble festivals where giants cheer on their champions, making bold boasts and challenges. At other times, the informal ceremony can become a chaotic free-for-all where both clans rush into a melee that fells trees, shatters the ice on frozen lakes, and causes avalanches on the snowy mountainsides.

entries.name: Make War, Not Goods
entries: Though frost giants consider the menial crafting of goods beneath them, carving and leatherwork are valued skills. They make their clothing from the skins and bones of beasts, and carve bone or ivory into jewelry and the handles of weapons and tools. They reuse the weapons and armor of their smaller foes, stringing shields into scale armor and lashing sword blades to wooden hafts to make giant-sized spears. The greatest battle trophies come from conquered dragons, and the greatest frost giant jarls wear armor of dragon scales or wield picks and mauls made of a dragon's teeth or claws.

entries.name: Giants
entries: Ancient empires once cast long shadows over a world that quaked beneath the giants' feet. In those lost days, these towering figures were dragon slayers, dreamers, crafters, and kings, but their kind fell from glory long ago. However, even divided among secluded clans scattered throughout the world, the giants maintain the customs and traditions of old.

entries.name: Old as Legend
entries: In remote regions of the world, the last remaining plinths, monoliths, and statues of the great giant empires bow their heads in desolate obscurity. Where once those empires sprawled across all lands, now the giants dwell in isolated tribes and clans.

Giants are almost as old as dragons, which were still young when the giants' heavy feet first shook the foundations of the world. As they spread across new lands, giants and dragons fought bitter generational wars that nearly brought both sides low. No living giant remembers what started the conflict, but myths and tales of their race's glorious dawn are still sung in their steadings and holdfasts, vilifying the primeval wyrms. Giants and dragons continue to harbor grudges against one another, and it is seldom that they will meet or occupy the same area without a fight.

entries.name: The Ordning
entries: Each of the main giant races-the cloud, fire, frost, hill, stone, and storm giants-are related by common elements of history, religion, and culture. They view one another as kindred, keeping any inherent animosity over territory and ambition to a minimum.

Giants belong to a caste structure called the ordning. Based on social class and highly organized, the ordning assigns a social rank to each giant. By understanding its place in the ordning, a giant knows which other giants are inferior or superior to it, since no two giants are equal. Each of the giant races analyzes a different combination of skills or qualities to determine the ordning. Giants make excelling in these qualities the purpose of their lives.

At the highest level of the ordning, the races of the giants are also ranked according to status. Storm giants are the highest in the ordning, followed by cloud giants, fire giants, frost giants, stone giants, hill giants, and finally giant kin such as fomorians, ettins, and ogres.

Regardless of a giant's rank among its own race, the chief of a hill giant tribe is inferior to the most common of stone giants. The lowest ranked giant of any type is superior to the highest ranked giant of an inferior type. It isn't considered evil to disrespect or even betray a giant of another type, merely rude.

entries.name: Giant Gods
entries: When the giants' ancient empires fell, Annam, father of all giants, forsook his children and the world. He swore never to look upon either again until the giants had returned to their glory and reclaimed their birthright as rulers of the world. As a result, giants pray not to Annam but to his divine children, along with a host of hero-deities and godly villains that make up the giants' pantheon.

Chief among these gods are the children of Annam, whose sons represent each type of giant: Stronmaus for storm giants, Memnor for cloud giants, Skoraeus Stonebones for stone giants, Thrym for frost giants, Surtur for fire giants, and Grolantor for hill giants. Not all giants automatically revere their kind's primary deity, however. Many good cloud giants refuse to worship the deceitful Memnor, and a storm giant dwelling in the icy mountains of the north might pay more homage to Thrym than Stronmaus. Other giants feel a stronger connection to Annam's daughters, who include Hiatea, the huntress and home warden; Iallanis, goddess of love and peace; and Diancastra, an impetuous and arrogant trickster.

Some giants abandon their own gods and fall prey to demon cults, paying homage to Baphomet or Kostchtchie. To worship them or any other non-giant deity is a great sin against the ordning, and almost certain to make a giant an outcast.

trait.name: Cold Aura
entries: The ground in a 10-foot radius around the giant is icy and is difficult terrain for creatures other than the giant. The radius moves with the giant and lasts until he dismisses it (no action required) or become {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the frost giant can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Icy Veins
entries: As a bonus action the giant cools down his blood hardening his muscles. The giant gains resistance to fire, bludgeoning, slashing and piercing damage but can't benefit from advantage on attack rolls. This effect lasts until the giant dismisses it with a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two greatsword attacks.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 7}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Ice Javelin
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 12} to hit, range 120/240 ft., one target. {@h}40 ({@damage 6d10 + 7}) cold damage and the target speed is halved.

action.name: Rock

trait.name: Extra Heads
entries: The giant has a {@chance 25} chance of having more than one head. If it has more than one, it has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, or knocked {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The giant regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the giant takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of its next turn. The giant dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

entries: The giant makes two Greataxe or Rock attacks.

bonus.name: Vaprak's Rage (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The giant enters a rage. The rage lasts for 1 minute or until the giant is {@condition incapacitated}. While raging, the giant gains the following benefits:

items: The giant has advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
When it makes a melee weapon attack, the giant gains a +4 bonus to the damage roll.
The giant has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

entries: To hold its place or rise within the ordning, a frost giant must routinely face mighty foes in single combat. Some seek out magic that will aid them, but enchanted objects can be taken or lost. True greatness relies on personal prowess. Faced with this truth, a frost giant might seek a supernatural gift from Vaprak the Destroyer.

Vaprak is a ferocious god of strength and hunger also worshiped by some ogres and trolls. He likes to tempt frost giants with dreams of glory followed by nightmares of bloody cannibalism. Those who don't shrink from such visions or report them to priests of Thrym receive more of the same. If a frost giant comes to relish these dreams and nightmares, as some do, Vaprak sets a troll upon a sacred quest to find the frost giant and meet the giant in secret. The troll offers up its own body to be devoured in Vaprak's name. Only the boldest and most determined frost giants can finish such a gory feast.

After devouring the troll sent by Vaprak, bones and all, a frost giant becomes an everlasting one, gaining tremendous strength, an ill temper, and a troll's regenerative ability. With these gifts, the frost giant can swiftly claim the title of jarl and easily fend off rivals for decades. However, if the frost giant doesn't give enough honor to Vaprak or fails to heed Vaprak's visions, injuries the frost giant sustains heal wrong, resulting in discolored skin; warty scars; and vestigial body parts, such as extra digits, limbs, and even heads. The touch of Vaprak can no longer be hidden then, and the everlasting one is either killed or exiled by their clan. Sometimes small communities of everlasting ones gather and even reproduce, passing the "blessing" and worship of Vaprak from one generation to the next.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The giant regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the giant takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of its next turn. The giant dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Multiple Arms
entries: The giant has four extra arms giving it more leeway to interact with the environment. It can pick up or interact with up to four items on its turn requiring no action.
Additionaly when a creature provokes an opportunity attack it can grapple the target instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes four attacks with its Frost Handaxes.
It can forgo two handaxes attacks to use its Rock, Fling or Fragmented Rock.

action.name: Frost Handaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 3d8 + 11}) slashing damage while raging.

action.name: Frost Handaxe (Throw)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 13} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 4d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature smaller than the giant, it must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Fling
entries: The giant tries to throw a Small or Medium creature within 10 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw or be hurled up to 60 feet horizontally in a direction of the giant's choice and land {@condition prone}, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown.

action.name: Fragmented Rock
entries: The giant shatters a huge boulder and hurls it in an area. Each creature in a 15-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 21 ({@damage 3d8+7}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: (GMA) - Squash|Esmagar - (GMA)
entries: O gigante se arremessa corporalmente em inimigos menores até 10-foot-radius, e os esmaga com seu peso, para isso o gigante faz uso de todo seu deslocamento. Uma criatura grande ou até 4 médias ou menores a até 5 feets uma da outra deve fazer um teste {@dc 15} de resistência de destreza, se falhar o alvo recebe 28 ({@damage 6d6+7}) de dano de bludgeoning. Além disso, o gigante fica {@condition prone} no espaço do alvo, e o alvo está {@condition restrained} e {@condition grapple}, no início do turno o alvo deve realizar um teste {@dc 15} de resistência de força encerrando o efeito em sucesso. Essas condições terminam cedo se o gigante se levantar.

action.name: (GMA) - Trample|Atropelar - (GMA)
entries: O gigante pode se mover normalmente por espaços ocupados por criaturas menores. Para fazer isso, o gigante deve fazer um teste de força (atletismo) resistida contra os alvos menores que estiverem no percurso. Se ele falhar, o movimento do gigante para naquele espaço e ele perde o resto do seu deslocamento. Se o gigante estiver duas ou mais categorias de tamanho acima, ele é automaticamente bem-sucedido. O gigante causa 11 ({@damage 1d8+7}) de dano de concussão em cada criatura que falhar no teste resistido.

action.name: (GMA) - Crush|Pisotear - (GMA)
entries: O gigante força um de seus pés sobre a cabeça de um alvo. A criatura deve ser bem sucedida em um teste {@dc 15} de resistência de Força. Em uma falha na resistência, a criatura está {@condition prone} e {@condition restrained}. No início de seu próximo turno, a criatura pode fazer um teste de força {@dc 15} (atletismo) ou destreza (acrobacia) para escapar. Se obtiver sucesso, a criatura vai para um espaço adjacente não ocupado e pode agir normalmente. Se o gigante se afastar da criatura, ela não está mais {@condition restrained}.

action.name: (GMA) - Jump|Salto - (GMA)
entries: O gigante salta sobre uma superfície, gerando um tremor e potencialmente desequilibrando as criaturas que estiverem sobre a superfície que o gigante aterrissar, para isso o gigante faz uso de todo seu deslocamento, podendo ainda assim aterrissar em algum ponto a 20 feets de onde estava. As criaturas que estiverem a 10 feets do gigante ou sobre ele devem ser bem sucedidas em um teste {@dc 15} de resistência de destreza, em uma falha a criatura está {@condition prone}. Adicionalmente, se houver alguma criatura no espaço do gigante enquanto ele realiza esta ação, o teste de resistência deve ser feito com desvantagem, em uma falha o alvo sofre 20 ({@damage 3d8+7}) de dano de concussão, em sucesso o alvo recebe apenas metade do dano.

bonus.name: Everlasting Fury
entries: The giant is always seething with rage. As long as the giant is not {@condition incapacitated} it is raging and gains the following benefits:
- The giant has advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws
- When it makes a melee weapon attack, the giant gains a +4 bonus to the damage roll.
- Ranged weapon attacks doesn't impose disadvantage if they are made using strength.
- The giant has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the frost giant mauler can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two Maul attacks. It can replace one of its attacks with Maul (Pushing Attack), Maul (Smash attack) or Ground Pound if it is available.

action.name: Maul
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 6d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Maul (Pushing Attack)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 6d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage, if the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Dexterity or Strength saving throw or be thrown up to 20 feet away, If a thrown target strikes a solid surface, the target takes ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown and becomes {@condition prone}.

action.name: Maul (Smash attack)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 feet, one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 6d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage, if the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Dexterity or Strength saving throw or be crushed, the crushed target takes 11 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage and becomes {@condition prone}.

action.name: Ground Pound {@recharge 5}
entries: The giant slams its maul on the ground, triggering an earth tremor and violently pelting the area with debris. Each creature on the ground originating from the giant in a 15-foot cube must succeed on a {@dc 20} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 28 ({@damage 6d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. If a creature fails its save by 5 or more, it is also {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 12} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 4d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature smaller than the giant, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

Adicionalmente, se houver alguma criatura no espaço do gigante enquanto ele realiza esta ação, o teste de resistência deve ser feito com desvantagem, em uma falha o alvo sofre 20 ({@damage 3d8+6}) de dano de concussão, em sucesso o alvo recebe apenas metade do dano.

Most frost giants fight with axes and blades, but these fearsome warriors prefer wielding great mauls as they enjoy hearing the sounds of crunching bones and shattering skulls. Frost giant maulers have perfected the art of smashing the ground with their mauls, knocking over nearby foes.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The frostmage's spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 19}, {@hit 11} to hit). The frostmage can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

1e: {@spell summon greater demon|XGE} (up to CR 9, it's obedient)

trait.name: Piercing Gold
entries: The frostmage's attacks ignore cold resistance.
Additionally when the frostmage hits a creature that is {@condition restrained} by Deepfreeze, the creature has vulnerability to cold damage.

trait.name: Deepfreeze {@recharge 5}
entries: When the frostmage hits a creature with an attack that deals cold damage it can use its bonus action to freeze the target in place,  the target must make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw. On a faild save it takes {@damage 4d8} cold damage and becomes {@condition restrained}, on successful save it only takes half the damage.
A creature can spend its action to make a {@dc 19} Strength saving throw to try to break free from the ice.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: When the frostmage dies, the rune on your mask explodes in a burst of jagged ice. Each creature within 20 feet of it must then succeed on a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 32 ({@dice 8d8}) slashing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The frostmage makes two coldfist attacks.

action.name: Coldfist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 1d12 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus ({@damage 2d12}) cold damage.

action.name: Frostball
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 11} to hit, range 240 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d10 + 6}) cold damage.

action.name: Fling
entries: The giant tries to throw a Small or Medium creature within 10 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or be hurled up to 60 feet horizontally in a direction of the giant's choice and land {@condition prone}, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown.

Gigantic reavers from the freezing lands beyond civilization, frost giants are fierce, hardy warriors that survive on the spoils of their raids and pillaging. They respect only brute strength and skill in battle, demonstrating both with their scars and the grisly trophies they take from their enemies.

entries.name: Hearts of Ice
entries: Frost giants are creatures of ice and snow. Their hair and beards are pale white or light blue, matted with frost and clattering with icicles. Their flesh is as blue as glacial ice.

Frost giants dwell in high peaks and glacial rifts where the sun hides its golden head by winter. Crops don't grow in their frozen homelands, and they keep little livestock beyond what they capture in their raids against civilized lands. They hunt the wild game of the tundra and mountains but don't cook it, since meat from a fresh kill tastes sufficiently hot to their palate.

entries.name: Reavers of the Storm
entries: The war horns of the frost giants howl as they march from their ice fortresses and glacial rifts amid the howling blizzard. When that storm clears, villages and steadings lay in ruins, ravens descending to feed on the corpses of any creatures foolish or unlucky enough to stand in the giants' path.

Inns and taverns suffer the brunt of the damage, their cellars gutted and their casks of ale and mead gone. Smithies are likewise toppled, their iron and steel claimed. Curiously undisturbed are the houses of moneylenders and wealthy citizens, for the reavers have little use for coins or baubles. Frost giants prize gems and jewelry large enough to be worn and noticed. However, even those treasures are most often saved for trading opportunities with other giants more adept at crafting metal weapons and armor.

entries.name: Rulers by Might
entries: Frost giants respect brute strength above all else, and a frost giant's place in the ordning depends on evidence of physical might, such as superior musculature, scars from battles of renown, or trophies fashioned from the bodies of slain enemies. Tasks such as hunting, childrearing, and crafting are given to giants based on their physical strength and hardiness.

When frost giants of different clans meet and their status is unclear, they wrestle for dominance. Such meetings might resemble festivals where giants cheer on their champions, making bold boasts and challenges. At other times, the informal ceremony can become a chaotic free-for-all where both clans rush into a melee that fells trees, shatters the ice on frozen lakes, and causes avalanches on the snowy mountainsides.

entries.name: Make War, Not Goods
entries: Though frost giants consider the menial crafting of goods beneath them, carving and leatherwork are valued skills. They make their clothing from the skins and bones of beasts, and carve bone or ivory into jewelry and the handles of weapons and tools. They reuse the weapons and armor of their smaller foes, stringing shields into scale armor and lashing sword blades to wooden hafts to make giant-sized spears. The greatest battle trophies come from conquered dragons, and the greatest frost giant jarls wear armor of dragon scales or wield picks and mauls made of a dragon's teeth or claws.

entries.name: Giants
entries: Ancient empires once cast long shadows over a world that quaked beneath the giants' feet. In those lost days, these towering figures were dragon slayers, dreamers, crafters, and kings, but their kind fell from glory long ago. However, even divided among secluded clans scattered throughout the world, the giants maintain the customs and traditions of old.

entries.name: Old as Legend
entries: In remote regions of the world, the last remaining plinths, monoliths, and statues of the great giant empires bow their heads in desolate obscurity. Where once those empires sprawled across all lands, now the giants dwell in isolated tribes and clans.

Giants are almost as old as dragons, which were still young when the giants' heavy feet first shook the foundations of the world. As they spread across new lands, giants and dragons fought bitter generational wars that nearly brought both sides low. No living giant remembers what started the conflict, but myths and tales of their race's glorious dawn are still sung in their steadings and holdfasts, vilifying the primeval wyrms. Giants and dragons continue to harbor grudges against one another, and it is seldom that they will meet or occupy the same area without a fight.

entries.name: The Ordning
entries: Each of the main giant races-the cloud, fire, frost, hill, stone, and storm giants-are related by common elements of history, religion, and culture. They view one another as kindred, keeping any inherent animosity over territory and ambition to a minimum.

Giants belong to a caste structure called the ordning. Based on social class and highly organized, the ordning assigns a social rank to each giant. By understanding its place in the ordning, a giant knows which other giants are inferior or superior to it, since no two giants are equal. Each of the giant races analyzes a different combination of skills or qualities to determine the ordning. Giants make excelling in these qualities the purpose of their lives.

At the highest level of the ordning, the races of the giants are also ranked according to status. Storm giants are the highest in the ordning, followed by cloud giants, fire giants, frost giants, stone giants, hill giants, and finally giant kin such as fomorians, ettins, and ogres.

Regardless of a giant's rank among its own race, the chief of a hill giant tribe is inferior to the most common of stone giants. The lowest ranked giant of any type is superior to the highest ranked giant of an inferior type. It isn't considered evil to disrespect or even betray a giant of another type, merely rude.

entries.name: Giant Gods
entries: When the giants' ancient empires fell, Annam, father of all giants, forsook his children and the world. He swore never to look upon either again until the giants had returned to their glory and reclaimed their birthright as rulers of the world. As a result, giants pray not to Annam but to his divine children, along with a host of hero-deities and godly villains that make up the giants' pantheon.

Chief among these gods are the children of Annam, whose sons represent each type of giant: Stronmaus for storm giants, Memnor for cloud giants, Skoraeus Stonebones for stone giants, Thrym for frost giants, Surtur for fire giants, and Grolantor for hill giants. Not all giants automatically revere their kind's primary deity, however. Many good cloud giants refuse to worship the deceitful Memnor, and a storm giant dwelling in the icy mountains of the north might pay more homage to Thrym than Stronmaus. Other giants feel a stronger connection to Annam's daughters, who include Hiatea, the huntress and home warden; Iallanis, goddess of love and peace; and Diancastra, an impetuous and arrogant trickster.

Some giants abandon their own gods and fall prey to demon cults, paying homage to Baphomet or Kostchtchie. To worship them or any other non-giant deity is a great sin against the ordning, and almost certain to make a giant an outcast.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The owlbear has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The owlbear makes three attacks: two with its claws and one with its beak. If both claw attacks hit a Huge or smaller creature, the target takes an extra 9 ({@damage 2d8}) slashing damage and must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) slashing damage.

reaction.name: Iron Endurance (2/Day)
entries: When the Owlbear takes slashing, piercing or bludgeoning damage, it halves the damage.

trait.name: Three-Headed
entries: The chimera has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the Ancient Arctic Chimera - mfh fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The chimera makes four attacks: one with its lion head's bite, one with its dragon head's bite, one with its horns, and one with its claws or tail. When his cold breath is available, he can use breath weapon and make a claw attack.

action.name: Dragon Head's Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 3d10 + 7}) percing damage plus 4 ({@dice 1d8}) cold.

action.name: Lion Head's Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d8 +7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Horns
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Cold Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon head exhales cold in a 40-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw, taking 72 ({@damage 16d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: (GMA) - Shake | Chacoalhar - (GMA)
entries: A quimera se chacoalha com o objetivo de arremessar qualquer criatura que estiver sobre ele.  Cada criatura que estiver sobre a quimera deve ser bem sucedida em um teste {@dc 15} de resistência de Força. Em uma falha a criatura é arremessada 20 feets e fica {@condition prone}, caso colida contra uma estrutura sólida o criatura arremessada recebe ({@damage 2d6}) de dano de bludgeoning.

action.name: (GMA) - Landing | Pouso - (GMA)
entries: A quimera se lança em direção a uma superfície e realiza um pouso estrondoso. A quimera pode realizar esse pouso desde de que esteja a ao menos 120 feets da superfície escolhida, e pode se deslocar até 20 feets da sua posição no início do turno durante processo de pousar, a quimera faz uso de todo seu deslocamento para isso. Cada criatura no espaço que a Quimera pousar deve ser bem sucedido em um teste {@dc 15} de resistência de Destreza feito com desvantagem, em uma falha o alvo sofre ({@damage 1d8}) de dano de bludgeoning para cada 20 feets que a quimera percorreu até a superfície e a criatura está {@condition prone}, em um sucesso a criatura recebe apenas metade do dano. Adicionalmente, para cada 20 feets que a quimera percorreu até a superfície o alcance desta habilidade aumenta em 5 feets centrado no local de pouso da quimera, todas as criaturas nesta área e sobre a quimera realizam o teste de resistência de Destreza normalmente e não recebem dano algum em uma falha mas estão {@condition prone}.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The chimera makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The chimera moves up to half its speed.

legendary.name: Tail
entries: The chimera makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Lion's Roar (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The chimera's lion head emits a magical roar. Each creature within 120 feet that can hear its roar must succeed on a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw or be and {@condition frightened} for one minute. If a creature fails its saving throw by 5 or more, the creature is also {@condition paralyzed} while {@condition frightened} for the same duration. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the Lion's Roar the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Three-Headed
entries: The chimera has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The chimera makes four attacks: one with its lion head's bite, one with its dragon head's bite, one with its horns, and one with its claws or tail.

action.name: Dragon Head's Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) percing damage plus 4 ({@dice 1d8}) cold.

action.name: Lion Head's Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) percing damage.

action.name: Horns
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Cold Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon head exhales cold in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 54 ({@damage 12d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The giant casts one of the following spells using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks):

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two melee attacks or two ranged attacks.

action.name: Battleaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) slashing damage, or 21 ({@damage 3d10 + 5}) slashing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one creature. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) cold damage and if the target is a creature, it can't use reactions until the end of the giant's next turn.

action.name: Summon Wolves (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The giant summons {@dice 4d6} wolves, {@dice 3d4} dire wolves, or {@dice 1d4} winter wolves. The wolves appear in unoccupied spaces within 30 feet of the giant and acts as its allies. The wolves act right after the giant on the same initiative count and fight until they're destroyed. They remain for 1 hour, until they or the giant dies, or until the giant dismisses them as an action.

action.name: Fling
entries: The giant tries to throw a Small or Medium creature within 10 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or be hurled up to 60 feet horizontally in a direction of the giant's choice and land {@condition prone}, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 4d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature smaller than the giant, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Fragmented Rock
entries: The giant shatters a huge boulder and hurls it in an area. Each creature in a 15-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 17 ({@damage 3d6+5}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: (GMA) - Squash|Esmagar - (GMA)
entries: O gigante se arremessa corporalmente em inimigos menores até 10-foot-radius, e os esmaga com seu peso, para isso o gigante faz uso de todo seu deslocamento. Uma criatura grande ou até 4 médias ou menores a até 5 feets uma da outra deve fazer um teste {@dc 13} de resistência de destreza, se falhar o alvo recebe 26 ({@damage 6d6+5}) de dano de bludgeoning. Além disso, o gigante fica {@condition prone} no espaço do alvo, e o alvo está {@condition restrained} e {@condition grapple}, no início do turno o alvo deve realizar um teste {@dc 13} de resistência de força encerrando o efeito em sucesso. Essas condições terminam cedo se o gigante se levantar.

action.name: (GMA) - Trample|Atropelar - (GMA)
entries: O gigante pode se mover normalmente por espaços ocupados por criaturas menores. Para fazer isso, o gigante deve fazer um teste de força (atletismo) resistida contra os alvos menores que estiverem no percurso. Se ele falhar, o movimento do gigante para naquele espaço e ele perde o resto do seu deslocamento. Se o gigante estiver duas ou mais categorias de tamanho acima, ele é automaticamente bem-sucedido. O gigante causa 10 ({@damage 1d8+5}) de dano de concussão em cada criatura que falhar no teste resistido.

action.name: (GMA) - Crush|Pisotear - (GMA)
entries: O gigante força um de seus pés sobre a cabeça de um alvo. A criatura deve ser bem sucedida em um teste {@dc 13} de resistência de Força. Em uma falha na resistência, a criatura está {@condition prone} e {@condition restrained}. No início de seu próximo turno, a criatura pode fazer um teste de força {@dc 13} (atletismo) ou destreza (acrobacia) para escapar. Se obtiver sucesso, a criatura vai para um espaço adjacente não ocupado e pode agir normalmente. Se o gigante se afastar da criatura, ela não está mais {@condition restrained}.

action.name: (GMA) - Jump|Salto - (GMA)
entries: O gigante salta sobre uma superfície, gerando um tremor e potencialmente desequilibrando as criaturas que estiverem sobre a superfície que o gigante aterrissar, para isso o gigante faz uso de todo seu deslocamento, podendo ainda assim aterrissar em algum ponto a 20 feets de onde estava. As criaturas que estiverem a 10 feets do gigante ou sobre ele devem ser bem sucedidas em um teste {@dc 13} de resistência de destreza, em uma falha a criatura está {@condition prone}. Adicionalmente, se houver alguma criatura no espaço do gigante enquanto ele realiza esta ação, o teste de resistência deve ser feito com desvantagem, em uma falha o alvo sofre 20 ({@damage 3d8+5}) de dano de concussão, em sucesso o alvo recebe apenas metade do dano.

reaction.name: Protective Wolf
entries: When the giant is hit by an attack, one allied wolf within 5 feet of the giant must use its reaction to be hit by the attack instead.

The wolflord is a cunning beastmaster who trains and commands dire wolves and winter wolves. It is also a formidable archer, able to shoot enchanted frost arrows that can pierce through the bodies of several enemies.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the giant fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant uses Maneuver Allies, if available. It then makes two Battleaxe attacks.

action.name: Battleaxe
entries: {@atk mw} +11 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) slashing damage, or 22 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) slashing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} +11 to hit, reach 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Maneuver Allies {@recharge 5}
entries: Up to four allies within 60 feet of the giant that can hear it can each use their reaction to move up to half their speed without provoking {@action attack of opportunity|phb|opportunity attacks}.

action.name: War Cry (1/Day)
entries: Each creature of the giant's choice that is within 30 feet of it, can hear it, and not already affected by War Cry gain advantage on attack rolls until the start of the giant's next turn. All other creatures within 30 feet of it, can hear it, and not already affected by War Cry must make a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until the end of the giant's next turn. The giant can then make one attack as a bonus action.

bonus.name: Battle Command
entries: The giant targets one ally it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can see or hear the giant, the target can use its reaction to make one melee attack or to take the {@action Dodge} or {@action Hide} action.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The giant moves up to half its speed.

legendary.name: Kick Ice
entries: The giant kicks ice and snow in a 15-foot cone. Each Medium or smaller creature in the area must succeed on a {@dc 19} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} and {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn. The giant must be standing on icy or snowy ground to use this action.

legendary.name: Cunning Instruction
entries: The giant targets one ally it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can see or hear the giant, the target gains advantage on its next attack roll, ability check, or saving throw until the start of the giant's next turn.

legendary.name: Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The giant makes a melee or ranged attack.

The gritty frost giant warlord is a charismatic leader who inspires courage within its allies and terror among its enemies. It is also a master tactician able to read the battlefield and is always one step ahead of everyone, issuing swift commands to its troops to ensure they gain the upper hand over their foes.
